body_html:
I ran into the same issue as @kalle, where setting num_epochs gave me the "Attempting to use un-initialized value" error. And like @kalle, I was initializing all variables like I am supposed to.

To fix it, I tried running tf.initialize_local_variables, but with num_epochs set, I still get the same error. I even tried including the global variable initialization, if only to cover my bases, and that didn't help either.

I can control the number of epochs through a For loop and catch the exception using Try-Except when the loop ends. But it would be more elegant to not have to catch that exception in the first place.

I can control the number of epochs through a For loop and catch the exception using Try-Except when the loop ends. But it would be more elegant to not have to catch that exception in the first place.
body:
I ran into the same issue as @kalle, where setting num_epochs gave me the "Attempting to use un-initialized value" error. And like @kalle, I was initializing all variables like I am supposed to. 

To fix it, I tried running tf.initialize_local_variables, but with num_epochs set, I still get the same error. I even tried including the global variable initialization, if only to cover my bases, and that didn't help either.

I can control the number of epochs through a For loop and catch the exception using Try-Except when the loop ends. But it would be more elegant to not have to catch that exception in the first place.
